Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but at the time when this papyrus was written, biblical names were no longer exclusively Jewish, see Introduction 6.5.5, especially in Egypt, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.

This papyrus is from a group discovered in Egypt but written in Pahlavi script. These are Sasanian administrative documents from the short period when Egypt was under Sasanian occupation between 616 and 629 CE. It may be assumed that the persons mentioned in them were part of the Sasanian administration in Egypt at the time, but were of Iranian provenance.

person.note: Although Hyman, Toldoth, 129, identifies him as Palestinian, because he transmits traditions in the name of Rabbi Yohanan and perhaps also Rabbi Asi (although there are mss differences there as he himself admits – for both see vol. 2), he is mentioned only in BT, bears the title רב consistently (see Introduction 6.6.1) and is also found in the presence of Babylonian amoraim (as Rav Ḥisda – Ḥesediah [1]), see e.g. bPes 33b). I therefore conclude that it is much more likely that he was Babylonian.

So in the Munich 95 Ms. On such a suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.5.1. It could, however, be referring to the word “his brother” rather than to a name, see above, n. 1. Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:21. The word אחא means brother in Aramaic. On family members as names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15. On the name and its meaning as a problem see bBB 167a: ההוא דהוה כתב ביה מנת ראובן ושמעון אחי. הוה להו אחא דשמיה אחי, אזל כתב ביה וי"ו ושויה ואחי; אתא לקמיה דאביי, אמר ליה: מאי טעמא דחיק ליה עלמא להאי וי"ו כולי האי? כפתיה ואודי (There was that person who wrote in it: For Reuven and Simon my brothers [Ahai]. He had a brother named Ahai. He went and inserted a waw and it became “and my brother” [or ve-Ahi]. [This Ahi] came to Abbaye [to demand his part in the gift] [Abbayye asked him] what is the reason for the way the waw is inserted like this. He forced him to admit [that he had falsified the waw]). The name אחא in Palmyra is feminine (see CIS 2/3, 4254-5; 4366).

The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is mentioned in vol. 1. (Elhanan [2], B/M) p. 62, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.

The formula בי בר is common in BT, see Introduction 6.10.1. The text here refers either to בי רב אלישיב (school of Rav Elyashib) in which case the school is named after this rabbi, or to בי בר אלישיב.

He is named in the geneaology of the Jewish tribes in Medina Banū Qurayẓa and Banū al-Naḍīr. It is impossible to date him more precisely, see Introduction 8.3.3.
This is Josephus’ orthography for the biblical figure with this name (Schalit, NB, 42), and see vol. 1, Eleʿazar (2), pp. 65, 70, p. 2.

This person is described as having been alive at the death of Jesus and having brought his cloak from Jerusalem to Georgia. This is obviously a fictitious composition.

Described as a contemporary of Rabbah bar bar Hanna (see vol. 2), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (see vol. 2), who died in 279 CE, according to ShGa § 165, see Introduction 8.2.1.
The Vilna edition has אליעזר, but the best mss have אלעזר.
In Aramaic – זעירא.
Appears in rabbinic literature, has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5, and is associated in this tradition with the House of the Exilarch, see Introduction 6.6.1.
Was a contemporary of Samuel (1), who died in 253 CE, according to ShGa § 161 CE, see Introduction 8.2.1.
So in the printed version. For this sort of abbreviation and suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.1, p. 25. For the additional י as an indicator of another dialect see Introduction 2.3.5.
So in the mss. For this sort of abbreviation and suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.1, p. 25.
Appears in rabbinic literature, and is associated in this tradition with the rabbinic courts of law, see Introduction 6.6.3.
He is a contemporary of Rav Pāpā (2), who died in 375 CE, according to ShGa § 176, see Introduction 8.2.1.
In Judeo-Arabic, see Introduction 2.8.7.
In Judeo-Arabic – אצחב מחמד.

In Judeo-Arabic – האולו הם אלי' אלדין גאו אליה ואסלמו עלי ידיה דלא יציב ישראל שי (These were they who came to him and adopted Islam in his presence in order that no harm might befall Israel), see Introduction 6.1.3.1.
On the names in this list see Introduction 6.10.3.
Was a contemporary of Muḥammad, who died in this year, see Introduction 8.3.2.

Although the inscription is found on the wall of a pagan temple (see Introduction 6.8) it is in Jewish (rather than Palmyrene) characters, see Introduction 6.2. Also, the names are biblical, although this is not strictly a clear indication of Jewishness in Palmyra, see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date assumed, see Introduction 8.4.3.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction. 6.4.1. This person is mentioned in vol. 1 (Eleazar [74] B/M) p. 67, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
On this sort of Babylonian abbreviation see Introduction 2.3.6.
Appears in rabbinic literature associating with rabbis, see Introduction 6.6.3.
So according to ShGa § 178, and see Introduction 8.2.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. On this sort of Babylonian abbreviation see Introduction 2.3.6.
See above, n. 3. Appears in rabbinic literature associating with rabbis, see Introduction 6.6.3.

person.note: So according to ShGa § 189, and see Introduction 8.2.1.
This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.3.
The inscription is, apparently, dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.

state.note: Levi (1)’s son, servant of the mesaiah, Christian martyr

person.note: In Syriac script, see Introduction 2.8.1. The additional vowel represents another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.2.
In Syriac ܥܒܕ ܠܡܝܣܝܚ . The text is a story of his martyrdom.

The text tells of his being born Jewish (ܝܘܕܝܐ in Syriac), see Introduction 6.1. His conversion is described in the text with the words ܣܗܕܘܬܐ ܕܓܒܪܐ ܕܐܠܗܐ ܥܒܕ ܠܡܝܣܝܚ ܕܗܘܐ ܥܒܕܐ ܕܡܫܝܚܐ ܕܐܝܬܘ ܗܘܐ ܫܡܗ ܐܫܝܪ ܒܪ ܠܘܝ (The martyrdom of the man of God Abd l’Masih, who is the slave of the Messiah, whose name was Ashir bar Levi, see Introduction 6.1.4).
The text places him in ܫܢܓܪ (Shingar, perhaps biblical שנער).
The text dates his martyrdom to this year, see Introduction 8.1.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2, and the name is biblical, see Introduction 6.5.
Date suggested by the editor, see Introduction 8.4.2.3.
The additional vowel represents another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.2.
Appears in rabbinic literature, and his son is described in this tradition as associating with the rabbis, see Introduction 6.6.3.

If this is not the biblical name (see Introduction 6.5.1), being a single father’s name, it answers the criteria of a nickname, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46. Whether the same criteria apply for the Eastern Diaspora must remain an open question.
His son transmits a tradition in the name of Samuel (1), who died in 253 CE, according to ShGa § 161, see Introduction 8.2.1.
The additional vowel represents another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.2.

person.note: His son was a contemporary of Ravina [Abbin (5)], who died ca. 420 CE, see Hyman, Toldoth, 1091-2, and Introduction 8.2.4.

It is not clear whether this inscription is in Aramaic or in Parthian, see Introduction 2.8.6. This reading is according to the Aramaic understanding. According to this reading, the final ו is a scribal or reading error, see Introduction 2.7.1.
On the Parthian inscriptions from the Dura synagogue see Introduction 6.3.1.

There is a disagreement about the reading of this inscription. So, according to the Aramaic, see above, n. 14. It is not clear whether this inscription is in Aramaic or in Parthian, see Introduction 2.8.6. This reading is according to the Aramaic understanding. According to this reading, the final ו is a scribal or reading error, see Introduction 2.7.1. If it is Parthian a completely different name is read, see under Sihār (1) I/M.
This is the date on which the synagogue was incorporated into the earthworks of the city fortification and destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.2.
On the א as vowel see Introduction 2.3.5.3. The וי suffix is probably the result of Iranian influence, see Introduction 2.4.1.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7, and this name may be understood not as biblical but rather as a general Semitic one, see Introduction 6.5.1.

The additional א vowels represent another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.3.

See above, n. 20. On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

person.note: See above, n. 21. The additional א vowels represent another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.3. On the final ו as an alternative suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.5.1, p. 28. It could of course also be a scribal or reading error, see Introduction 2.7.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 19. The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7, and this name may be understood not as biblical but rather as a general Semitic one, see Introduction 6.5.1.

person.note: Appears in rabbinic literature as the father of a rabbi, see Introduction 6.6.2. He has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5.

If this is not the biblical name (see Introduction 6.5.1), being a single father’s name, it answers the criteria of a nickname, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46. Whether the same criteria apply for the Eastern Diaspora must remain an open question.
His son was a student of Rava (Abba [17]), who died in 352 CE, according to ShGa § 176, see Introduction 8.2.1.
In Aramaic – די צרו צורתא הדא (who created this picture).

The editor thought he was Jewish because of the biblical name, but this is not necessary, see Introduction 6.5.1. He is here engaged in creating a pagan edifice. IJO 3, App22, read his name differently (בר יה[יבא]) and concluded that there is nothing Jewish in the inscription.
This word need not be a name. It may be the Aramaic “his son.”
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
The loss of the final vowel represents another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.4.
In Aramaic – גנזכייא, see Oppenheimer, Babylonia Judaica, 120-6.
A similar tradition is found in bNid 65a but the name and place of origin are completely corrupted (בנימין/מנימין סקסונאה/סבסאה). No such place names are known.
Appears in rabbinic literature, has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5, and is mentioned in association with the rabbinic academies, see Introduction 6.6.3.
Ginzaq is in Persia, see above, n. 3. In Aramaic – גנזכייא, see Oppenheimer, Babylonia Judaica, 120-6.
Was a contemporary of Samuel (1), who died in 253 CE, according to ShGa § 161 CE, see Introduction 8.2.1.
In Aramaic – רעיא.
Appears in rabbinic literature, has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5, and is mentioned in this tradition as saying a blessing on the food, under rabbinic scrutiny, see Introduction 6.6.3.
In yBer 6:2, 10b, the same tradition is told of a nameless person, who is described as a Persian (פרסוי).
He is a contemporary of Rav (Abba [70]), who died in 247 CE, according to ShGa § 160, see Introduction 8.2.1.
On this form see vol. 1, Benjamin (4) B/M, pp. 82-3, n. 10.

Described in this tradition as a slave, and thus probably not born Jewish, but he does have a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5. On Benjamin being a preferred name for proselytes, see vol. 1, p. 83, n. 11. See also Introduction 6.1.2.
A contemporary of Rav Ashi (1), who died in 427 CE, according to ShGa § 186, see Introduction 8.2.1.

So in the Vilna print and in most mss. On this form see above, n. 12. On this form see vol. 1, Benjamin (4) B/M, pp. 82-3, n. 10. The fall of the vowel is probably another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.4. But in the Munich 95, the Oxford Opp. Add. fol. 23, and the Vatican 134 mss the version is בנימין.
Appears in rabbinic literature, interpreting Scripture, see Introduction 6.6.3.
His brother is described as a contemporary of Samuel (1), who died in 253 CE, according to ShGa § 161 CE, see Introduction 8.2.1.
All three versions (בנימין/מנימין/מניומי) appear in the various mss traditions, see above, n. 12. On this form see vol. 1, Benjamin (4) B/M, pp. 82-3, n. 10. For מניומי, see under Manyumi (S-H/M).
Appears in rabbinic literature and bears the title רב (Rav), see Introduction 6.6.1.
His Babylonian provenance is only evident from bḤul 80a.

In Aramaic – אסיא. Probably identical with מניומי אסיא (bShab 133b; bAZ 28b). On this name see under Manyumi (S-H/M).

His family is described in this tradition as being in conflict with the rabbis, precisely because they are Jewish, but represent a different variety of Judaism, see Introduction 6.6.3. Also, he has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5.
Is mentioned by Rava (Abba [17]) who died in this year, according to ShGa § 176, see Introduction 8.2.1.
On this form see vol. 1 Benjamin (4) B/M, pp. 82-3, n. 10.
In Aramaic – כנדוקא. כנדא means pot in Aramaic. Rashi interpreted this name as meaning “pottery dealer.”
Appears in rabbinic literature, and is found in association with rabbis, see Introduction 6.6.3.
Was a contemporary of Rava (Abba [17]), who died in 352 CE, according to ShGa § 176, see Introduction 8.2.1.

The script and the Aramaic of the document have been identified by the editor, in comparison with other material, as Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.
The papyrus is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.

person.note: In Aramaic – אפותיקי. The reading is according to Naveh, OSM, 139, no. 103.
This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.3.
This was the date when the new Dura synagogue was built. However, this inscription was displayed in the old synagogue.
On the Greek form of this name see vol. 1, p. 83, n. 2. The initial ιis the result of iotacism, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Benjamin [8], B/M) p. 82, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

In Judeo-Arabic, see Introduction 2.8.7.
In Judeo-Arabic – אצחב מחמד. He was “killed in the ways of God”. In Judeo-Arabic – אלמקתול פי סביל אללה.

In Judeo-Arabic – האולו הם אלי' אלדין גאו אליה ואסלמו עלי ידיה דלא יציב ישראל שי (These were they who came to him and adopted Islam in his presence in order that no harm might befall Israel). This is a Jewish apologetic text, which speaks of Muḥammad’s Jewish companions, who joined Islam, see Introduction 6.1.3.1.
On the names in this list see Introduction 6.10.3.
Was a contemporary of Muḥammad, who died in this year, see Introduction 8.3.2.
Appears in rabbinic literature, has a biblical name (see Introduction 6.6) and his son bears the title רב (Rav), see Introduction 6.6.2.
He is a Babylonian rabbi, transmitting a tradition in the name of a late tanna, see Introduction 8.2.6.

The name of this person in the mss of bSan 17b and bMeg 18b is usually ברכיה. Yet it is not always stable, and must have been unknown to the scribes, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. In the Vilna print of bMeg 18 he is identified as רמי בר חמא, and see under Ami (3) S-H/M. In this form he is recorded in the Jerusalem– Yad Harav Herzog 1 Ms. For the י suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.1. The additional י as vowel is probably an indication of another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.2.
So in the Munich 95 Ms, and see previous note. For the י suffix on the biblical ברוך see Introduction 2.3.3.1.

So in the Barko (1598) Ms, and see above, n. 4. The name of this person in the mss of bSan 17b and bMeg 18b is usually ברכיה. Yet it is not always stable, and must have been unknown to the scribes, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. In the Vilna print of bMeg 18 he is identified as רמי בר חמא, and see under Ami (3) S-H/M. In this form he is recorded in the Jerusalem– Yad Harav Herzog 1 Ms. For the י suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.1. The additional י as vowel is probably an indication of another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.2. The כ instead of ב, and י instead of ו, are probably scribal or reading errors, see Introduction 2.7.1.

So in the London – BL Harl. 5508 (400) Ms to bMeg 18b, see above, n. 4. The name of this person in the mss of bSan 17b and bMeg 18b is usually ברכיה. Yet it is not always stable, and must have been unknown to the scribes, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. In the Vilna print of bMeg 18 he is identified as רמי בר חמא, and see under Ami (3) S-H/M. In this form he is recorded in the Jerusalem– Yad Harav Herzog 1 Ms. For the י suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.1. The additional י as vowel is probably an indication of another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.2. For this name see under Ḥabu S-H/M.

So in the Vatican 134 Ms to bMeg 18b, and see above, n. 4. The name of this person in the mss of bSan 17b and bMeg 18b is usually ברכיה. Yet it is not always stable, and must have been unknown to the scribes, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. In the Vilna print of bMeg 18 he is identified as רמי בר חמא, and see under Ami (3) S-H/M. In this form he is recorded in the Jerusalem– Yad Harav Herzog 1 Ms. For the י suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.1. According to SOZ, see Introduction 8.2.5.

In the Bible this is the name of an angel. Perhaps the scribe chose this name for himself to enhance his magical powers and it is no real name at all.

In Arabic script, see Introduction 2.8.8. In Hebrew this would read דני. On this suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.1. In Ṭabarī, i, 355, the father of the tribe of Dan is documented as دان (דאן). On the י suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1.

The biblical זמרי is transliteratedΖαμβρίας in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 49) and Ζαμβρεί in LXX (H & R Suppl. 65), and see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1, pp. 17-8. He is described in the text as ڧتعمذ بها واقام فيها مدة (“He was baptised and stayed [Christian] for a while”). His biblical name and provenance from Ḥimyar, which is described in the same chapter as leaning toward Judaism, suggest that he converted from Judaism.
The text describes the event as taking place at the time that Ḥimyar was ruled by a Jewish king (Joseph [36]). These are his dates.

The name was found on an ossuary in a cave with Latin names (e.g. ̓Αφρεικανός - Africanus). Abel (RB 10 [1913] 274), who first published the finds, suggested that this was the Latin name Anius. However, just as ̔́Αννας is traditionally understood as חנן, so too ̔́Ανιςcould be interpreted as חנין, see vol. 1 Hanan (19) B/M, pp. 99-101, n. 47.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person was recorded in vol. 1, (Hanan [19] B/M) p. 99, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

חננאל is transliterated in LXX as ̓Ανανιήλ (H & R Suppl. 17), see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1, pp. 17-8. This is Josephus’ declined version. On Josephus and LXX transliteration see vol. 1 Hananel (1) B/M, 102-3, n. 2.

Should probably be identified with חנמאל המצרי, see vol. 1, Hanamel (1), pp. 98-9, because rabbinic literature mentions the latter as an officiating high priest, and the assumption is that Josephus presents us with the complete list of Second Temple officiating high priests. The origin (Egyptian rather than Babylonian) may be a rabbinic distortion, based on confusion between this priest and Σίμων υἱὸς Βοηθοῦ (Simon son of Boethus, see vol.1, Simon [24], p. 219), the high priest who followed our ̓Ανάνηλος, who, according to Josephus, came from Egypt.

In Hebrew – הבבלי. As איסי הבבלי he appears in the Tosefta. In bMen 18a, in a tradition parallel to tZeb 2:17, he appears as יוסף הבבלי. In tPar 4:3 a certain יוסף הבבלי is mentioned. I assume they are the same. In PT (yBQ 3:7, 3d) he is designated יוסי הבבלי. BT (bYoma 52b) maintains that this person should be identified with איסי בן יהודה, and also with יוסף איש הוצל (Joseph [25]), with איסי בן גור אריה (vol. 1, Joseph [67] B/M), with איסי בן גמליאל (not mentioned in any tradition besides this one and its parallels), with איסי בן מהללאל (identified as an amora in bNid 36b) and ultimately with איסי בן עקביא (vol. 1, Joseph [64] B/M). bYoma 113b even adds יוסף איש צרידה (vol. 1, Joseph [44] B/M) to the list. This, however, is not very likely, because this particular Babylonian tradition about איסי בן יהודה seems to identify him with all persons named איסי in tannaitic literature, and some also named יוסף as one and the same. In PT (yBQ 3:7, 3d) the tradition also identifies this איסי with other sages – איסי בן יהודה, here designated יוסי (vol. 1, Joseph [47] B/M) and יוסי קטונתא (vol. 1, Joseph [43] B/M). Obviously, there was little known about these sages in later generations, although the fact that both BT and PT identify him with יוסי בן יהודה (vol. 1, Joseph [47] B/M) may suggest a more reliable source. And see יוסי בן יהודה איש כפר הבבלי (vol. 1, Joseph [47] B/M).

In Aramaic – סומקא. In bYev 64b the identification between the two is clearly made: כי אתא רב יצחק בר יוסף, אמר: עובדא הוה קמיה דר' יוחנן בכנישתא דמעון ביוה"כ שחל להיות בשבת, ומלה ראשונה ומת, שניה ומת, שלישית – באה לפניו, אמר לה: לכי ומולי. א"ל אביי: חזי דקשרית איסורא וסכנתא. סמך עלה אביי, ואזל נסבה לחומה ברתא דאיסי בריה דרב יצחק בריה דרב יהודה, דנסבה רחבא דפומבדיתא ושכיב, רב יצחק בריה דרבה בר בר חנה ושכיב, ונסבה הוא ושכיב. אמר רבא: ומי איכא דעביד עובדא בנפשיה כי האי? והא איהו דאמר: אבין דסמכא, יצחק סומקא לאו בר סמכא, אבין ישנו בחזרה, יצחק סומקא אינו בחזרה. (“When Rav Isaac son of Joseph came he related: Such a case was once submitted to R. Johanan in the Synagogue of Maʿon on the Day of Atonement, which fell on Shabbat. A woman had circumcised her child who died; her second [sister circumcised her child] and he also died, and her third sister appeared before him. He said to her: Go and circumcise him. Said Abbayye to him: See, you have permitted a forbidden and a dangerous act. Abbayye, however, relaying upon this statement, married Homa the daughter of Isi son of Rabbi Isaac the son of Rav Judah, although Rehaba of Pumpeditha had married her and died, and R. Isaac son of Rabbah bar Hana had subsequently married her and also died. Said Rava: Would anyone else have exposed himself to such danger? Surely he himself had said that Abbin was reliable but that Isaac Sumqa was was not a person to be relied upon; that Abbin was well aquainted with any such change [in the views of R. Johaman] but Isaac Sumqa was not aquainted with any such changes).

In all the printed editions he is designated so. But the biblical form, מלכיה, is recorded in many Mss., e.g. Goettingen 3, London – BL Harl. 5508 (400), Oxford Opp. Add. fol. 23 and Oxford – Bodl. heb. e. 52 (2678) to bBeṣ28b. On the interchange between the two forms in eastern dialects see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26.
So in Oxford Opp. Add. fol. 23 Ms to bShab 46a, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1 and next note. The interchange of י and כ may be understood as a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20.

There is much confusion between this sage and the next as BT clearly notices and repeatedly differentiates between them, see bBeṣ28b; bKet 61b; bAZ 29a; bMak 21a; bNid 52b. Yet there are three traditions in which the differentiating formula is not found (bShab 46a, bYev 113a, and bMen 9b) and there the mss versions are indeed confused. It seems, however, that bShab 46a refers to this rabbi and bYev 113a and bMen 9b refer to the next one.

person.note: In Arabic script, see Introduction 2.8.8. This is the usual Arabic transliteration of the Hebrew עזרא (according to Van Dyke Translation), but in the Qurʾān (9:30) a person usually identified with ʿEzra the scribe is written عزير (ʿUzayr). It is, however, not clear whether this identification is valid, see M. Sharon, “People of the Book,” EQ 4, (2004), 36-43. Ṭabarī, i, 669-70, gives the form عزير for Ezra the Scribe, but mentions also other, non-Jews by the name عزرة (I, 1790;II, 539;II, 134; II, 235). The form ‘ZR is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 417.

person.note: This is one possibile transliteration of the name שמואל into Arabic, although it is not recorded in any of the early Muslim sources for the biblical prophet, Samuel. On the interchange of ش and س see Introduction 2.3.4.1.

This papyrus is from a group discovered in Egypt but written in Pahlavi script. These are Sasanian administrative documents from the short period when Egypt was under Sasanian occupation. It may be assumed that the persons mentioned in them were part of the Sasanian administration in Egypt at the time, but were of Persian provenance.
These are the dates of the Sasanian occupation of Egypt, see previous note.

The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Simon [93], B/M) p. 221, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. This is a Jewish apologetic text, which speaks of Muḥammad’s Jewish companions, who joined Islam. In Judeo-Arabic – האולו הם אלי' אלדין גאו אליה ואסלמו עלי ידיה דלא יציב ישראל שי (These were they who came to him and adopted Islam in his presence in order that no harm might befall Israel).
On the names in this list see Introduction 6.10.3.

div.note: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 8:2.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 3:4. In the Bible this is a female name.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 22:20. אביתר was a priest under King David.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:5. אברהם is the name of the famous biblical patriarch, forefather of the Jewish people, and see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 3:3. אבשלום was David’s rebellious son.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 4:14. אהרן was the name of Moses’ brother, the first priest.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:21. The word אחא means brother in Aramaic. On family members as names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15. On the name and its meaning as a problem see bBB 167a: ההוא דהוה כתב ביה מנת ראובן ושמעון אחי. הוה להו אחא דשמיה אחי, אזל כתב ביה וי"ו ושויה ואחי; אתא לקמיה דאביי, אמר ליה: מאי טעמא דחיק ליה עלמא להאי וי"ו כולי האי? כפתיה ואודי (There was that person who wrote in it: For Reuven and Simon my brothers [Ahai]. He had a brother named Ahai. He went and inserted a waw and it became “and my brother” [or ve-Ahi]. [This Ahi] came to Abbaye [to demand his part in the gift] [Abbayye asked him] what is the reason for the way the waw is inserted like this. He forced him to admit [that he had falsified the waw]). The name אחא in Palmyra is feminine (see CIS 2/3, 4254-5; 4366).
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 11:29. אחיה was a prophet.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 21:19.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 23:20. אליקים was a king of Judah.
Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr. 24:12.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 19:16. אלישע was a prophet, and Elijah’s disciple.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23. אלעזר was Aaron the Priest’s son. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction, 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 48:5. אפרים was Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 3:21.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:13. אשר was one of the twelve tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 15:19. אתי was David’s general.

Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:11. The name is probably Aramaic, since it is only documented in post-exilic books of the Bible (Ezra, Neh). See also Lipiński, Studies 1, 111. On the suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.1.3, p. 24.
Biblical, Ezek 1:3. בוזי was the Prophet Ezekiel’s father.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 11:22. בניה is one of King David’s generals.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 35:18. בנימין is Jacob’s youngest son and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 32:12. ברוך was Jeremiah’s scribe.
Biblical, e.g. Zach 1:1.
Biblical, e.g. Daniel 8:16. גבריאל is the name of an angel.
Biblical, e.g. Num 1:10.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 16:13. דוד was the name of the famous king of Israel. It was seldom used as a personal name, see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:6. דן was one of Jacob’s sons.
Biblical, e.g. Dan 1:7. דניאל is the biblical figure who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 42:1.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 12:13. הלל was the name of a biblical judge.

Biblical, 1 Chr 8:17. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews. Various forms of the name are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 85-6); and in Idumea (AOFCI, 99). The names זבדא/זבדו/זבדי/זבודו/זבידו are recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 367-70, 372. The form ZBD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 294). The form ZBYDʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 18-9).
Biblical, e.g. Zech 1:1. זכריה is the prophet who gave the name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 16:9. זמרי was a king of Israel. For this name in Palmyra see Stark, PNPI, 86.
Biblical, e.g. Hag 1:12. חגי was the post-exilic prophet who gave the name to a biblical book.
Biblical, 1 Chr 1:46. חושם was the name of an Edomite king.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:1. חזקיה was king of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:37.

Biblical, e.g. Jer 35:4. This name has such an independent standing that one often loses sight of the fact that it is probably an abbreviation of חנניה, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29. Because this distinction is already biblical, I have not listed the two names under a single heading here.
Biblical, see e.g. Jer 31:38.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 28:1. חנניה was the name of one of Daniel’s mates who were thrown into the fiery furnace, see Dan 1:6.

Biblical, 1 Chr. 3:20. In vol. 1, (under חסדי S-H/M, pp. 384) I recorded variants of this name under Other (mostly Semitic) Names in the Hebrew Alphabet, because the biblical form of the name never showed up. In this volume it shows up once, so I recorded the name under biblical names, and see Introduction 2.3.3.5.

Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10. The most famous Τωβίας of Second Temple times are the heroes of the apocryphal book Tobit and his father, Τωβίθ. However, since the book is clearly fictitious, and refers to a time before the Hellenistic conquest, he is not included in this corpus, even if the book itself was composed in the Hellenistic period.
Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10. The longer form – יאשיהו – is the name of a king of Judah (2 Kgs 21:26).
Biblical, e.g. Neh 10:22. This name only appears in the Second Temple biblical book Nehemiah.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:35. יהודה was one of Jacob’s sons, and a tribe of Israel. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 17:9. יהושע was the name of the general, Moses’ successor, who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. 2Kgs 2:11. יואש was the name of a king of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 40:16. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 14:25. יונה was the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 13:2. יונתן was King Saul’s son. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:24. יוסף was a son of Jacob. The name was very popular, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. On the suggestion that it was also a name of a Hasmonean brother, see vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1.2.3, p. 7.
Biblical, e.g. Ezek 1:3. יחזקאל was a prophet who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:9.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:26. יעקב is the third Patriarch. On the popularity of the name see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 11:1. יפתח was one of the the Judges.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:19. יצחק is the second Patriarch. On the popularity of the name see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 27:1. ירמיה was the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 16:11. The biblical Ishmael, the first-born, rejected son of Abraham could not have been a likely role model for name giving. Nevertheless, it was very popular in Second Temple times, and seems to have already been in use among Jews toward the close of the First Temple Period (2 Kgs 25:25) and see also vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1.1, p. 6.
Biblical, e.g. Ezr 8:7. ישעיהו was the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:34. לוי was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel. A relevant question is whether all persons named Levi in this period were Levites? Harding, ICPIANI, 522, also records the form LWY but it obviously refers to a Jew.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 32:12.
Biblical e.g. Daniel 1:6. מישאל was one of Daniel’s friends who was cast into the fiery furnace.

Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 9:12. In vol. 1, (מלכה) S-H/M, pp. 390-1 and in vol. 3 (מלכא) S-H/M, pp. 674-7, I recorded variants of this name under Other (mostly Semitic) Names in the Hebrew Alphabet, because the biblical form of the name never showed up. In this volume it shows up once, so I recorded the name under biblical names, and see Introduction 2.3.3.5.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 13:12. מנוח was Samson’s father.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:14. מנחם was the one before last king of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 41:51. מנשה was Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Esth 2:1. מרדכי was Queen Esther’s uncle.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 2:10. משה was the name of the Israelite leader and law-giver. The name of Moses was not common among Jews during the Second Temple period, see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 22:3.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 24:17.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:43. This name is only documented in post-exilic biblical books (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.

Biblical, e.g. Nah 1:1. נחום was the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book. According to Noth, IPRGN, 38, נחום is a variation of נחמיה, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.4, p. 29. However, because the Bible distinguishes clearly between the two, they are listed here under two separate entries.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 1:1. נחמיה was the Jewish leader who gave his name to a historical biblical book.
Biblical, Neh 7:7.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:21.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:8. נפתלי was one of Jacob’s twelve sons and a tribe of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 7:2. נתן was the name of David’s prophet.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 6:29. The names ʿBDʾ and ʿBDY are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 102).
Biblical, e.g. Obad 1. עבדיה was the name of the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 7:4.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:22.
Biblical, Ezek 11:1.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 7:1. עזרא is the scribe who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:18. עמרם was Moses’ father.
Biblical, Neh 10:27.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:45. Obviously, here the Bible preserves the abbreviated form of the non-biblical עקביה, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.4, p. 29. For the Arabic (ʿQBT) see Harding, ICPIANI, 426.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 2:18. עשאל was Yoab’s brother.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:25. פנחס was the name of Aaron’s grandson. In the Bible the name is spelled as a rule פינחס.
Biblical, 1 Chr 3:24.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 15:24. צדוק was David’s priest, who founded the Zadokite dynasty.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 26:6. In the Bible this is the name of the mother of Yoav, David’s general.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:3. שבא was one of Abraham’s descendants from Qetura.
Biblical, e.g. Isa 22:15.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:15.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:3.

Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:13. שלום was the name of a king of Israel. Note that in vol. 1 (B/F, pp. 249-53 – 63 representatives) and in vol 3 (B/F, pp. 191-3 – 17 reresentatives) this is a female name and see also in this volume, Salome B/F. But see also vol. 3, B/M, pp. 160-1 (13 representatives), and Introduction 2.6.3.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 5:14. שלמה was the name of the son of David, king of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 37:3.
Biblical, e.g. Hos. 10:4.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 6:1. שם was the name of Noah’s son.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:20. שמואל was the prophet who gave his name to two biblical books. On the popularity of this name see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:33. שמעון was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel. Note also, that this is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 12:22.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 19:19. שפט was the name of the prophet Elisha’s father.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 9:4.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 4:25. שת was the name of Adam’s third son.
Biblical, 1 Chr 4:12.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:15. The name is associated with a son of Ishmael, i.e. it may be of Arab extraction. The name TYMʾ is recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 117.
